title: Government walks away from British bioethanol industry hit by Trump trade deal - Politico.eu
description:
LONDON — The U.K. government has ruled out stepping in to save two of the country’s key bioethanol producers, Vivergo Fuels and Ensus, from closure — after signing a trade deal allowing U.S. ethanol to flood the British market.
The government decided not to provide direct financial support, leaving 160 workers at Vivergo's Saltend-based plant facing redundancy, with layoffs set to begin on Monday.
Ensus' plant in Redcar is also at risk of closure.
Over 12,000 U.K. wheat farmers supply Vivergo's plant, which also produces high-protein animal feed.
Meanwhile, Ensus, one of the U.K.’s only other bioethanol producers, supplies around 30 percent of the country’s commercial carbon dioxide — needed for soft drinks and medical use.
text:
LONDON — The U.K. government has ruled out stepping in to save two of the country’s key bioethanol producers, Vivergo Fuels and Ensus, from closure — after signing a trade deal allowing U.S. ethanol to flood the British market.

The government decided not to provide direct financial support, leaving 160 workers at Vivergo's Saltend-based plant facing redundancy, with layoffs set to begin on Monday. Ensus' plant in Redcar is also at risk of closure.

In a statement, a government spokesperson said: “We have worked closely with the companies since June to understand the financial challenges they have faced over the past decade, and have taken the difficult decision not to offer direct funding as it would not provide value for the taxpayer or solve the long-term problems the industry faces.”

Vivergo’s future was thrown into doubt after the U.K.-U.S. trade deal, announced in May, opened the door to 1.4 billion liters of tariff-free American ethanol — almost equivalent to the size of the entire domestic market.

The decision has wider implications for other industries and investment into Britain. Vivergo had been lined up to supply feedstock for a £1.25 billion sustainable aviation fuel facility backed by Meld Energy — a project now on hold. Over 12,000 U.K. wheat farmers supply Vivergo's plant, which also produces high-protein animal feed.

Meanwhile, Ensus, one of the U.K.’s only other bioethanol producers, supplies around 30 percent of the country’s commercial carbon dioxide — needed for soft drinks and medical use.

“We recognize this is a difficult time for the workers and their families and we will work with trade unions, local partners and the companies to support them through this process,” said the government spokesperson. “We also continue to work up proposals that ensure the resilience of our CO2 supply in the long-term in consultation with the sector.”

The decision will also prove unpopular with voters in Hull, with the Saltend chemical park just a 10-minute drive away.

Reform UK's Luke Campbell, who recently swept into office as Hull an East Yorkshire mayor with nearly 50,000 votes, told POLITICO: “Labour’s decision not to provide support, and not to change the clause in their U.S.-U.K. Trade deal is incredibly disappointing. It means job losses and closures for hard working people.”

title: KWE and Shell Aviation sign new agreement on the use of SAF | Biomass Magazine
description:
Kintetsu World Express Inc. is pleased to announce that it has entered into a new agreement with Shell Aviation, regarding the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
KWE and Shell Aviation jointly participated in the market-based measures framework pilot demonstration program conducted by Smart Freight Centre in 2023.
Under this agreement, we will adopt Shell Aviation's digital platform "Avelia" to swiftly address shippers' low-carbon transportation needs.
Avelia will help KWE to access the environmental benefits of SAF even when SAF is not physically available at their locations.
SAF is a key component of our concrete efforts, and our collaboration with Shell Aviation represents a significant step forward for us."
text:
Kintetsu World Express Inc. is pleased to announce that it has entered into a new agreement with Shell Aviation, regarding the use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).

KWE and Shell Aviation jointly participated in the market-based measures framework pilot demonstration program conducted by Smart Freight Centre in 2023. Since then, we have been engaged in discussions to establish a secure and convenient mechanism for the use of SAF's environmental benefits by aviation stakeholders, including freight forwarders and shippers, engaging in air freight activities.

Under this agreement, we will adopt Shell Aviation's digital platform "Avelia" to swiftly address shippers' low-carbon transportation needs. Avelia will help KWE to access the environmental benefits of SAF even when SAF is not physically available at their locations. It also offers a transparent, secure, and credible blockchain platform that ensures traceability, and helps to prevent erroneous double counting.

Tatsuya Narasaki, Managing Officer at Kintetsu World Express, stated, "We have identified the reduction of CO2 emissions and the promotion of renewable energy use as key sustainability challenges. To mitigate the environmental impact of our global operations, we are working to reduce CO2 emissions not only in Japan but also around the world. We are pleased to announce that our near-term and long-term net-zero emissions reduction targets have been formally approved by SBTi. SAF is a key component of our concrete efforts, and our collaboration with Shell Aviation represents a significant step forward for us."

Doris Tan, Head of Shell Aviation, Asia Pacific and Middle East, stated, "We value our collaboration with KWE since the early days of the Smart Freight Centre's market based measures pilot. Through Avelia, we aim to accelerate SAF adoption and provide companies like KWE with a clear, scalable pathway to credible life cycle GHG emissions reductions* from aviation. This agreement marks another important step in making low-carbon air transport a reality for cargo stakeholders in Asia and beyond."

*For more information about Avelia, please visit: https://aveliasolutions.com/

*Compared to conventional jet fuel

title: Navigating the New Era of Airline Safety: Strategic Investment Opportunities in a Regulated Sky
description:
These enforcement actions highlight the operational and reputational costs of regulatory missteps, compelling airlines to invest in compliance infrastructure.
Undervalued Opportunities: Beyond the Traditional Carrier Model As traditional airlines struggle with regulatory and environmental headwinds, investors are increasingly turning to sectors with inherent resilience: digital rail, regional logistics, and digital travel platforms.
Digital Travel Platforms: Integrating Mobility Solutions Digital travel platforms are redefining consumer expectations by offering seamless, multimodal travel experiences.
Conclusion: A New Paradigm for Aviation Investing The post-pandemic aviation landscape is defined by regulatory scrutiny, environmental imperatives, and technological disruption.
By prioritizing investments in digital rail, regional logistics, and integrated travel platforms, investors can hedge against the volatility of the airline sector while capitalizing on the next wave of innovation in global mobility.
text:
The post-pandemic aviation industry is undergoing a seismic shift, driven by a confluence of regulatory rigor, technological adaptation, and evolving consumer expectations. As airlines grapple with the dual pressures of safety mandates and profitability, investors must discern which carriers and adjacent sectors are best positioned to thrive in this transformed landscape. Recent policy shifts—such as Emirates' power bank ban and the U.S. Department of Transportation's (DOT) accessibility reforms—underscore a broader industry pivot toward risk mitigation and operational resilience. This article examines the financial implications of these changes for major carriers and identifies undervalued aviation-related stocks poised to capitalize on the new normal.

Regulatory Evolution: Safety as a Strategic Imperative

The past two years have seen a surge in safety-focused regulations, reflecting a global prioritization of passenger welfare and risk reduction. Emirates' 2025 power bank ban, for instance, is emblematic of a sector-wide response to lithium-ion battery risks. By prohibiting in-flight charging and restricting storage to accessible locations, Emirates aims to minimize thermal runaway incidents—a growing concern as portable electronics proliferate. This policy aligns with similar measures by Asian carriers and the UK Civil Aviation Authority, signaling a coordinated effort to address a systemic hazard.

Meanwhile, the U.S. DOT has intensified its focus on disability accommodations, enforcing the Final Rule on Ensuring Safe Accommodations for Air Travelers with Disabilities Using Wheelchairs. This regulation, which mandates improved training and infrastructure for wheelchair handling, has already triggered significant penalties for non-compliant carriers. American Airlines, for example, faced a $50 million fine for mishandling wheelchairs, while Lufthansa was penalized $4 million for discriminatory practices. These enforcement actions highlight the operational and reputational costs of regulatory missteps, compelling airlines to invest in compliance infrastructure.

Financial Implications: Compliance Costs and Margin Compression

The financial burden of these regulations is substantial. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) estimates that CORSIA (Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation) compliance costs will reach $1 billion in 2025, while Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) expenses are projected to add $4.8 billion to industry costs. SAF, which remains 4.2 times more expensive than conventional jet fuel, is a particular strain on carriers in Europe and Asia, where mandates like the EU's ReFuelEU Aviation policy demand aggressive blending targets.

These costs are eroding profit margins, which are expected to hover at 3.7% in 2025—up marginally from 3.4% in 2024 but still below the global industrial average. Airlines are passing these expenses to consumers through higher ticket prices, but this strategy risks further demand suppression in a market still recovering from pandemic-induced volatility. For instance, Spirit Airlines' recent Chapter 11 emergence and “going concern” warning illustrate the fragility of carriers unable to balance compliance costs with revenue growth.

Undervalued Opportunities: Beyond the Traditional Carrier Model

As traditional airlines struggle with regulatory and environmental headwinds, investors are increasingly turning to sectors with inherent resilience: digital rail, regional logistics, and digital travel platforms. These industries are not only adapting to regulatory pressures but also leveraging technology to redefine mobility and supply chain efficiency.

Digital Rail: A Sustainable Alternative to Air Travel

The global digital railway market, projected to grow from $83.74 billion in 2024 to $230.60 billion by 2034, is a prime example of this shift. Union Pacific Corporation (NYSE: UNP), a leader in North American freight rail, has demonstrated robust operational resilience, with a 100-basis-point improvement in its operating ratio to 59.0% in Q2 2025. Its integration of AI and IoT for route optimization and predictive maintenance positions it as a key beneficiary of the post-pandemic shift toward sustainable infrastructure.

Regional Logistics: Powering E-Commerce Growth

The regional logistics sector, driven by e-commerce and urbanization, is another high-conviction area. FedEx (NYSE: FDX), for instance, has a Valuation Rating of B and a Due Diligence Score of 46—well above the logistics industry average. Its investments in electric delivery vehicles and AI-powered route planning have enhanced efficiency, with analysts projecting an 18.91% upside in its stock price. Similarly, ZTO Express (NYSE: ZTO), a dominant player in China's express delivery market, has leveraged automation and drone technology to expand its market share, achieving a 1.21% gain in 2025 despite sector-wide challenges.

Digital Travel Platforms: Integrating Mobility Solutions

Digital travel platforms are redefining consumer expectations by offering seamless, multimodal travel experiences. These platforms, which combine rail, regional air, and digital booking systems, are projected to capture 30% of the global travel market by 2030. Companies that integrate AI for real-time route optimization and dynamic pricing are particularly well-positioned to outperform traditional airlines, which face fare volatility and operational inefficiencies.

Investment Thesis: Balancing Risk and Resilience

For investors, the key lies in identifying assets that align with the long-term trajectory of the aviation ecosystem. While major carriers like Delta Air Lines (DAL) and United Airlines (UAL) have shown valuation rebounds, their high uncertainty ratings and thin margins make them speculative plays. Conversely, undervalued stocks in rail and logistics—such as FedEx, ZTO Express, and Union Pacific—offer a more stable path to growth, supported by structural trends like decarbonization, urbanization, and digital transformation.

Conclusion: A New Paradigm for Aviation Investing

The post-pandemic aviation landscape is defined by regulatory scrutiny, environmental imperatives, and technological disruption. While traditional carriers face margin compression and compliance challenges, adjacent sectors are emerging as beacons of resilience. By prioritizing investments in digital rail, regional logistics, and integrated travel platforms, investors can hedge against the volatility of the airline sector while capitalizing on the next wave of innovation in global mobility. In this new paradigm, operational resilience—rather than mere cost-cutting—will be the cornerstone of sustainable value creation.

outlet: North East Bylines | Powerful Citizen Journalism
title: From Woolsington to the world: celebrating 90 years of Newcastle Airport - North East Bylines
description:
Over the decades, Newcastle Airport has become far more than a place to catch a flight.
It is a civic symbol, an economic powerhouse, and a deeply personal landmark for generations of people in the North East.
Importantly, and a clear indication of the calibre of the team running the airport, it has also become a recognised leader in the aviation world.
Newcastle airport: a public asset What makes Newcastle International so exceptional is that it is owned by us – by the people of this region.
At 90 years old, Newcastle International Airport stands not at the end of an era, but at the beginning of its most exciting chapter yet.
text:
Over the decades, Newcastle Airport has become far more than a place to catch a flight. It is a civic symbol, an economic powerhouse, and a deeply personal landmark for generations of people in the North East.

During my time as a board member, I was proud to help shape a vision that looked beyond the airport’s role as a transport hub. I believed then, and believe now, that Newcastle International should be seen as a civic anchor and a catalyst for the future; a place that doesn’t just move people, but drives progress.

It is, above all, a window to the world. From family holidays and new business ventures to academic journeys and emotional reunions, it is a place tied to countless moments that matter.

It is a window to the world. For so many people in the North East, it is the place where journeys begin and end. It is where first holidays took off, where businesses shook hands with global markets, where students left for the unknown and returned wiser, and where families embraced with relief, excitement, or longing. It is a place woven into the emotional map of millions of lives.

How many stories could be told by those who passed through this airport over the past 90 years? How many lives changed by a single journey? How many relationships, careers, or ideas were born from its departure lounge? This airport is part of our region’s story – but it also holds the stories of the people who make this region what it is.

Every gate and departure board holds a million stories.

Today, the airport connects us to over 80 destinations through 16 airline partners, with onward links to more than 325 cities worldwide. It handled more than 5.1 million passengers in 2024, making it the 11th busiest airport in the UK. It’s consistently among the most efficient too – 98% of travellers clear security in under ten minutes.

Importantly, and a clear indication of the calibre of the team running the airport, it has also become a recognised leader in the aviation world. In 2024, Newcastle International was named Overall Winner at the Routes World Awards in Bahrain – the first UK airport ever to receive that honour – and also won UK & Ireland Airport of the Year from the Travel Trade Gazette. These aren’t just awards – they’re proof that a regional airport, owned by and for its region, can lead with pride on the global stage.

More than £20 million has been invested into terminal upgrades, including a fully refurbished departure lounge, next-generation security systems, and the world’s first three-tier Aspire Lounge. But what’s most important is what this investment represents: confidence – in the airport, in the region, and in the people it serves.

And yet, the most exciting part of Newcastle International’s story is not what it has achieved, but what lies ahead.

Newcastle airport: a low-carbon future

The airport is now a central partner in developing the North East Green Superport; what could be a transformational project to integrate air, sea, rail, and road to create a low-carbon logistics and freight network. This isn’t just a port strategy – it’s a new model for regional economic development, rooted in sustainability, innovation, and inclusion. The airport’s role within this network will go far beyond passengers. It will serve as a strategic export hub, connecting regional manufacturing, green energy, and innovation sectors to global markets.

This vision also aligns with the airport’s firm commitment to achieving Net Zero by 2035. This is a target underpinned by serious action: electrifying ground operations, investing in sustainable aviation fuel, and collaborating with universities and tech partners on aviation decarbonisation. Aviation must be part of the climate solution, and Newcastle is stepping forward to prove that it can be.

Newcastle airport: a public asset

What makes Newcastle International so exceptional is that it is owned by us – by the people of this region. Through our local authorities, we have a stake in its success. That means its profits, priorities, and plans are not dictated from afar but shaped by local needs and local people.

It is rooted in public purpose. Its profits are reinvested. Its priorities reflect regional needs. It is accountable not only to passengers, but to the communities of Newcastle, Gateshead, Sunderland, Durham, Northumberland, and South Tyneside.

Looking ahead, I’m sure the airport will continue to play a leading role – not just in infrastructure or transport, but in telling the story of the North East to the world. Championing cultural exports, opening new trade routes, supporting creative industries, attracting inward investment, and inspiring the next generation to see the world as theirs to shape.

It means being bolder than ever: investing in green aviation innovation, becoming a testbed for regional skills and careers, supporting inclusive growth, and ensuring that the people who live near the airport also benefit from its success – in jobs, education, and opportunity.

At 90 years old, Newcastle International Airport stands not at the end of an era, but at the beginning of its most exciting chapter yet. It is no longer simply a place of departures and arrivals; it is a launchpad for ideas, innovation, and ambition. A civic asset with global reach. A regional institution with a world-class future.

It has helped generations of North Easterners see the world, and now it’s helping the world see us – not as a peripheral region, but as a centre of climate leadership, industry, creativity, and possibility.

So, here’s to the past 90 years of flight, of stories, and of connection. And here’s to what comes next:

title: Africa's youth is fighting injustice with memes - Thred Website
authors: Derrick Wachaya, Jessica Byrne, Flo Bellinger, Anyaa Shrii Kumar, Jamie Watts
description:
Across the continent, memes have emerged as one of Gen Z’s sharpest weapons against injustice, a digital dialect of rebellion where punchlines deliver punches to power.
Welcome to Africa’s meme wars, where humor is resistance, virality is visibility, and Gen Z doesn’t just witness history, they remix it.
In Sudan, as young people protested the military’s grip on power, memes comparing the generals to outdated phone apps or expired milk flooded WhatsApp groups.
In Kenya, Gen Z memes recently took on a historic role during the 2024 Finance Bill protests.
African Gen Z isn’t just laughing.
text:
If you’re African and online, chances are your first taste of politics came not from a news broadcast, but from a meme.

A screenshot. A freeze-frame. A line of text in Impact font. Maybe it made you laugh, then made you think. Maybe it made you mad enough to post, to protest, to speak. Across the continent, memes have emerged as one of Gen Z’s sharpest weapons against injustice, a digital dialect of rebellion where punchlines deliver punches to power.

Say goodbye to long speeches and manifestoes. Welcome to Africa’s meme wars, where humor is resistance, virality is visibility, and Gen Z doesn’t just witness history, they remix it. Memes, once considered funny internet detritus, have become tools of socio-political commentary in African digital life.

During the 2020 Nigeria #EndSARS protests against police brutality, memes took the place of protest banners. Stringing together viral images of a cartoon SpongeBob designed as a Nigerian protester, phrases like ‘Soro Soke’ (‘speak up’ in Yoruba) became a meme, a slogan, but overall a movement. The digital rebellion moved into the streets and, in time, government crosshairs.

In Sudan, as young people protested the military’s grip on power, memes comparing the generals to outdated phone apps or expired milk flooded WhatsApp groups. The goal? To ridicule the regime and rally the masses without triggering heavy-handed crackdowns.

In Kenya, Gen Z memes recently took on a historic role during the 2024 Finance Bill protests. A widely shared meme showed a stock photo of a lion captioned: ‘When the government realizes Gen Zs read more PDFs than they thought.’ Another showed a politician trying to ‘block’ a protester, only to be digitally photoshopped out by a cartoon eraser.

Meme Activism across the continent

Let’s take a minute to take stock of just how Gen Z is mobilizing for justice through memes. When it came to the 2021 elections, social media was flooded with memes satirizing President Yoweri Museveni’s long rule. One viral image showed Museveni as the ‘admin’ of an old, dusty WhatsApp group titled ‘Presidents Since 1986.’

During 2021’s July unrest, memes emerged both to criticize looting and highlight racial inequality. One depicted a white-owned mall labeled ‘protected’ and a township with ‘forgotten’ pasted over it.

In the wake of Egypt’s Arab Spring fallout, memes have quietly persisted. Satirical pages like El Koshary Today use humor to critique the military regime without triggering arrests, walking a dangerous line.

Gen Zs aren’t waiting for mainstream media to report the story. They become the media. A meme produced in Nairobi is now reposted in Accra, reshared in Kigali, and moments later creates a protest in Kinshasa.

Most meme-makers occupy anonymity. They are operating behind burner accounts and encrypted apps. This is digital guerilla warfare, creative, chaotic, and deeply political. And while some elders scoff at memes as ‘childish,’ these same graphics are turning into flashpoints for reform.

Just ask President Ruto from Kenya who was the target of thousands of meme-based critiques during the 2024 tax protests. The memes became so popular that mainstream media started airing and referencing them in their coverage, forcing policy exemplars to include them in their discussions.

Meme activism in Africa isn’t all fun and punchlines and meme pages have been linked to arrests. In Nigeria, authorities monitor social media for ‘cybercrime’ under vague laws. Several meme creators have faced threats, digital surveillance, or doxxing.

And with the rise of AI-generated memes, governments are tightening their grip on misinformation laws, sometimes using that as an excuse to suppress dissent. The meme wars may be hilarious, but they are fought under real risk.

In a continent where democratic backsliding and youth suppression are rampant, memes are offering a lifeline to resistance, a bridge between information and emotion, between power and the powerless. African Gen Z isn’t just laughing. They’re organizing. They’re calling out hypocrisy while expressing it in the language they are fluent in, the language of memes.

title: Renewable Energy Megaprojects - Clean the Sky
description:
Simply Blue Group is advancing a multibillion-dollar renewable energy hub on Nova Scotia’s Eastern Shore that integrates wind, solar and biomass to produce sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
The facility will convert renewable electricity, local biomass and water resources into roughly 150,000 tonnes of SAF per year, which offers a 90 percent reduction in greenhouse-gas emissions compared to conventional jet fuel.
To ensure feedstock supply, Simply Blue has signed an agreement with Wagner Forest Management to source 700,000 tonnes of residual biomass annually, with stockpiling to begin several years before production.
After investing tens of millions in engineering and feasibility studies, the project was transitioned in mid-2025 to Octopus Energy Generation under the Nova Sustainable Fuels entity, and a memorandum of understanding was signed with Nova Scotia Mi’kmaw Chiefs to guide responsible development.
Image Credit: Pieridae Energy
text:
Simply Blue Group is advancing a multibillion-dollar renewable energy hub on Nova Scotia’s Eastern Shore that integrates wind, solar and biomass to produce sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). The company has secured approximately 755 acres of contiguous land in Goldboro—266 acres acquired from Pieridae Energy and 489 acres from the Municipality of Guysborough—to host a processing plant powered by electricity from a dedicated transmission line connected to a joint wind and solar farm in St. Mary’s. The facility will convert renewable electricity, local biomass and water resources into roughly 150,000 tonnes of SAF per year, which offers a 90 percent reduction in greenhouse-gas emissions compared to conventional jet fuel.

To ensure feedstock supply, Simply Blue has signed an agreement with Wagner Forest Management to source 700,000 tonnes of residual biomass annually, with stockpiling to begin several years before production. After investing tens of millions in engineering and feasibility studies, the project was transitioned in mid-2025 to Octopus Energy Generation under the Nova Sustainable Fuels entity, and a memorandum of understanding was signed with Nova Scotia Mi’kmaw Chiefs to guide responsible development. With a final investment decision slated for 2026 and operations targeted for 2029, the project is expected to create hundreds of local jobs and establish a new market for forestry residues while contributing to regional economic growth and Canada’s decarbonization goals.

Image Credit:

Pieridae Energy

title: Dallas Love Field Expanding Capacity for Private Jets | Luxury Travel Advisor
description:
Business Jet constructing two new hangars at its Dallas Love Field (KDAL) location, as demand for aircraft services continues to rise in the region.
Scheduled for completion in January 2026, this development brings Business Jet’s total footprint to 475,000 square feet of hangar and office space across 19 hangars and two executive terminals.
The other is designed to accommodate multiple tenants with seven individual office and shop spaces to meet customer needs.
“This nearly 70,000 square foot project represents the latest in a multi-phased development plan designed to meet hangar and office space demand at Business Jet.
Beyond this phase, we're excited to have the capacity to build another 100,000 square feet at KDAL to support future operations,” said Chris Wright, partner and CEO.
text:
Business Jet constructing two new hangars at its Dallas Love Field (KDAL) location, as demand for aircraft services continues to rise in the region. Scheduled for completion in January 2026, this development brings Business Jet’s total footprint to 475,000 square feet of hangar and office space across 19 hangars and two executive terminals. The Fixed-Based Operator (FBO) expansion comes at a time of ongoing growth for the company, which recently dedicated two existing hangars to enhance its Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul (MRO) capabilities.

The new side-by-side hangars are designed with 28-foot hangar doors to easily accommodate the latest ultra-long-range aircraft, such as the Gulfstream G700 and Bombardier Global 7500. Each hangar is unique with one serving a single tenant in a build-to-suit space featuring custom designs and elevated lobby finishes. The other is designed to accommodate multiple tenants with seven individual office and shop spaces to meet customer needs. The hangars feature epoxy-coated floors, LED lighting, large format fans, radiant tube heating, electric vehicle (EV) chargers and integrated utility pedestals with 208/480/115-amp power, water and compressed air.

“This nearly 70,000 square foot project represents the latest in a multi-phased development plan designed to meet hangar and office space demand at Business Jet. Beyond this phase, we're excited to have the capacity to build another 100,000 square feet at KDAL to support future operations,” said Chris Wright, partner and CEO. “This expansion plan reflects our ongoing commitment to supporting discerning customers in all aspects of their aircraft operations.”

As business aviation shows no sign of slowing down, Business Jet is poised to accommodate aircraft owners and operators with the top-of-the-line facilities and customer service.

title: How Cutting-Edge Innovation and Sustainability Are Transforming the Global Air Cargo Industry
description:
The global air cargo industry, traditionally associated with speed and reliability, is now facing a dual challenge—meeting surging demand from e-commerce, pharmaceuticals, and high-value goods, while reducing its environmental impact.
Innovation Takes Flight Modern air cargo hubs are embracing automation, artificial intelligence, and blockchain to streamline operations.
Sustainability Becomes a Business Imperative The environmental footprint of air cargo has long been under scrutiny.
For cargo operators, staying relevant will mean investing in greener fleets, smarter logistics, and transparent operations.
The Way Forward Air cargo is no longer just about speed—it’s about smart, sustainable, and responsible growth.
text:
The global air cargo industry, traditionally associated with speed and reliability, is now facing a dual challenge—meeting surging demand from e-commerce, pharmaceuticals, and high-value goods, while reducing its environmental impact.

Post-pandemic trade patterns, coupled with stricter emission regulations, are forcing cargo operators, airlines, and logistics companies to innovate faster than ever before.

Innovation Takes Flight

Modern air cargo hubs are embracing automation, artificial intelligence, and blockchain to streamline operations. AI algorithms now optimise cargo space, predict demand surges, and track shipments in real time, reducing delays and costs.

Blockchain-enabled platforms ensure transparency in the supply chain, making it harder for counterfeit goods to slip through.

Air freight Rates Hold Steady As They Go Through Turbulence

Meanwhile, drones and autonomous aircraft are becoming viable for short-haul and last-mile cargo delivery. These innovations are particularly valuable for urgent medical supplies, high-value electronics, and critical parts in remote locations.

Sustainability Becomes a Business Imperative

The environmental footprint of air cargo has long been under scrutiny. With aviation contributing nearly 2% of global CO₂ emissions, the sector is now under pressure to decarbonise. Airlines and cargo operators are investing in Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), which can cut lifecycle emissions by up to 80%.

Companies like DHL, FedEx, and Emirates SkyCargo are experimenting with electric and hybrid aircraft, while others are testing lightweight packaging and optimised flight paths to reduce fuel burn.

Governments and industry bodies, including IATA, have set ambitious goals to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, pushing carriers to accelerate their green transitions.

Technology Meets Regulation

Regulatory frameworks are evolving to encourage greener operations. Carbon offset schemes, tax incentives for SAF adoption, and stricter emissions reporting are becoming standard.

In parallel, digital customs clearance systems are reducing paperwork and expediting cross-border trade, improving efficiency and cutting idle times at airports—a subtle but significant sustainability gain.

The Road (and Sky) Ahead

The next decade will likely see a blending of sustainability and technology as the industry’s competitive edge. Electric cargo planes could dominate regional routes, while AI-driven predictive maintenance will make fleets more reliable and energy-efficient.

For cargo operators, staying relevant will mean investing in greener fleets, smarter logistics, and transparent operations.

The Way Forward

Air cargo is no longer just about speed—it’s about smart, sustainable, and responsible growth. The industry is undergoing a transformation that aligns profitability with environmental stewardship.

By embracing innovation and sustainability together, the sector can ensure that future trade flows as smoothly through green skies as it does through global markets.

title: RGE Bankers' Forum 2025: Sustainable Growth for a New World Order
description:
The 2025 RGE Bankers’ Forum convened over 200 regional and international banking partners at Singapore’s Fullerton Hotel to discuss “Sustainable Growth for a New World Order”.
Together, we explored evolving market trends, global risks, and long‑term strategic opportunities.
Senior leadership from RGE shared how the group is expanding its global footprint, diversifying across regions and sectors, and expanding into adjacent growth areas to drive sustainable, profitable growth.
Global Leadership across Core Segments Royal Golden Eagle (RGE) is a leader in bio‑based resources and energy, operating across more than 100 markets worldwide.
Strategic diversification into adjacent growth areas including solar energy, sustainable aviation fuel, and B2C consumer products provides additional synergy and growth pathways.
text:
The 2025 RGE Bankers’ Forum convened over 200 regional and international banking partners at Singapore’s Fullerton Hotel to discuss “Sustainable Growth for a New World Order”. Together, we explored evolving market trends, global risks, and long‑term strategic opportunities.

Senior leadership from RGE shared how the group is expanding its global footprint, diversifying across regions and sectors, and expanding into adjacent growth areas to drive sustainable, profitable growth. These efforts are guided by disciplined execution and a long‑term mindset.

Global Leadership across Core Segments

Royal Golden Eagle (RGE) is a leader in bio‑based resources and energy, operating across more than 100 markets worldwide. It is the world’s largest producer of dissolving pulp, viscose, and lyocell, and consistently ranks among the top three global producers of paperboard, printing and writing paper, and market pulp. RGE also ranks second globally in palm oil refining. These positions stem from disciplined vertical integration and strategic investments, including the acquisitions of Vinda in China and Origami in India, making RGE a leading consumer tissue producer in both markets.

Since the inaugural Bankers’ Forum in 2019, RGE’s assets have more than doubled, successfully delivering large‑scale international projects. Notably, we are developing the world’s first net‑zero LNG export facility in Canada and Southern Europe’s largest second-generation biofuels plant in Spain.

Integrated, Diversified Portfolio and Future Preparedness

RGE’s five core verticals – pulp and paper; dissolving and specialty pulp; textile fibres; palm oil; and energy – cover upstream assets like plantations and gas fields through to downstream products such as tissue, garments, biodiesel, and electricity. This integrated value chain ensures quality control, cost competitiveness, and environmental governance. Strategic diversification into adjacent growth areas including solar energy, sustainable aviation fuel, and B2C consumer products provides additional synergy and growth pathways.

With recent major projects nearing completion, RGE is well-positioned for continued growth despite global uncertainties, including volatility from US tariffs and shifting supply chain dynamics. We remain committed to disciplined execution, agility, and preserving margins through brand strength.

Strategic Vision for the New Global Environment

RGE President Tey Wei Lin shared insights on the importance of supply chain diversification, flexible business models, and scenario planning to navigate geopolitics and trade protectionism. He underscored that strong future leadership requires balancing long‑term vision with agile near‑term execution – “think harder, react faster”.

Wei Lin summarised RGE’s future growth directions:

Strengthen leadership in core upstream sectors and expand selectively downstream.

Grow B2C tissue and personal care business by leveraging our leading brands.

Pivot to green energy, including sustainable aviation fuel and solar, leveraging our competitive advantages and strong partnerships.

As Managing Director Belinda Tanoto emphasised in her closing remarks, we are guided by our 5Cs operating philosophy – that what we do must be good for the Community, Country, Climate, Customer and only then will it be good for the Company. RGE’s global ambitions are anchored in partnerships – particularly with our banking and financial community – as we aim to deliver profitable growth with sustainability at its core.

title: Advocacy group offers unflattering chemical recycling portrayal - Waste Today
description:
The Washington-based Environmental Integrity Project, in a mid-August online article posted to its Oil & Gas Watch website, says it has identified nine operating plastics chemical recycling plants in the United States, although numerous others are under construction or have been proposed.
The organization contrasts the nine operating plants with what it calls “a flurry of ambitious announcements” about plastics recycling facilities that will deploy processes including pyrolysis, gasification, solvolysis and solvent-based purification collectively known as chemical recycling or advanced recycling.
Also drawing skepticism is the Brightmark Plastics plant in Ashley, Indiana.
“The company never managed to get the plant up and running at commercial scale and filed for bankruptcy in March,” notes the advocacy group.
“In May, the company bought itself back at auction with the hope of keeping the facility operational,” adds the organization.
text:
The Washington-based Environmental Integrity Project, in a mid-August online article posted to its Oil & Gas Watch website, says it has identified nine operating plastics chemical recycling plants in the United States, although numerous others are under construction or have been proposed.

The organization contrasts the nine operating plants with what it calls “a flurry of ambitious announcements” about plastics recycling facilities that will deploy processes including pyrolysis, gasification, solvolysis and solvent-based purification collectively known as chemical recycling or advanced recycling.

A list posted within the article lists three plants under construction and another 19 that have been proposed. A separate map, also included on the article page, displays about three dozen facilities, including some of the under construction and proposed ones. Nine others are identified as operating and 10 others described as “canceled [or] shut down.”

The text of the Oil & Gas Watch article focuses on idled facilities, including the Regenyx facility in Tigard, Oregon, described as having reached just 40 percent of its designed capacity and has having “sustained operating losses of $22.4 million in 2020 and 2021.”

The organization also describes the Fulcrum BioEnergy waste-to-jet fuel plant in Nevada as having “struggled to keep operations running consistently” the company as having failed to repay government bonds. “It was shut down in May 2024 after operating for only two years [and] Fulcrum filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in September of last year, canceling projects it planned to develop in Indiana and Texas,” writes Alexandra Shaykevich of Oil & Gas Watch.

Also drawing skepticism is the Brightmark Plastics plant in Ashley, Indiana. “The company never managed to get the plant up and running at commercial scale and filed for bankruptcy in March,” notes the advocacy group.

The Environmental Integrity Project, citing Plastics News, says the bankruptcy filing showed the Ashley plant was only operating at 5 percent capacity and, as of 2023, had processed around 2,000 tons of plastic scrap in total. “In May, the company bought itself back at auction with the hope of keeping the facility operational,” adds the organization.

While in its report the Environmental Integrity Project quotes a researcher who describes all plastic recycling as ineffective, packaging, recycled materials and waste handling companies—as well as some plastics producers—around the world have continued to invest in mechanical recycling projects that have tended be based on longer term return on investment calculations.

title: New report: Pacific Northwest Low-Carbon Hydrogen Analysis
description:
The Pacific Northwest Economic Region (PNWER) published a major study that provides a comprehensive view of supply, demand and trade opportunities for low-carbon hydrogen between Washington, British Columbia and the broader Pacific Northwest.
Key recommendations Share data and coordinate hydrogen project planning and initiatives across the Pacific Northwest.
This partnership will invite more agencies and ministries involved in the regional low-carbon hydrogen industry to find better ways to work together.
Commerce will also continue engaging with tribal nations across Washington to understand how the state can support their desired levels of involvement in a growing regional low-carbon hydrogen economy.
Further, PNWER is planning to lead the establishment of a Pacific Northwest Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) Coalition in partnership with the Pacific Northwest Hydrogen Association and Montana Renewables.
text:
The Pacific Northwest Economic Region (PNWER) published a major study that provides a comprehensive view of supply, demand and trade opportunities for low-carbon hydrogen between Washington, British Columbia and the broader Pacific Northwest. This analysis is the result of a multi-year partnership between Commerce, the British Columbia Ministry of Energy and Climate Solutions, PNWER, and Deloitte.

The study was developed to enable policymakers, industry stakeholders, tribal nations and regional partners to better understand the economic and energy landscape, funding tools and policy frameworks that support the development and deployment of low-carbon hydrogen. Commerce’s 2024 legislative report on green electrolytic hydrogen and renewable fuels informed the study’s key supply and demand modeling. This study is an important resource for building a strong cross-border hydrogen economy that attracts investment, supports multiple industries, and supports high-quality jobs across the region.

Key recommendations

Share data and coordinate hydrogen project planning and initiatives across the Pacific Northwest.

Seek ways to align policies that facilitate cross-border hydrogen development, including funding mechanisms and seamless trade.

Find opportunities to work with tribes, First Nations and local communities so they are involved and benefit. This includes sharing educational resources, building partnerships, and supporting indigenous voices.

Promote regional hubs and cross-border transportation routes that support hydrogen and synthetic fuel use.

Next steps

Commerce will continue collaborating with the British Columbia Ministry of Energy and Climate Solutions to explore ways to put key recommendations into place, especially those focused around policy and regulatory alignment. This partnership will invite more agencies and ministries involved in the regional low-carbon hydrogen industry to find better ways to work together.

Commerce will work with regional hydrogen industry and stakeholder groups, including PNWER, to expand regional coordination on low-carbon hydrogen and create new ways to share knowledge, build partnerships, and collaborate on key markets and other critical topics. Commerce will also continue engaging with tribal nations across Washington to understand how the state can support their desired levels of involvement in a growing regional low-carbon hydrogen economy.

Further, PNWER is planning to lead the establishment of a Pacific Northwest Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) Coalition in partnership with the Pacific Northwest Hydrogen Association and Montana Renewables. Modeled after the Minnesota SAF hub, the coalition will convene regional stakeholders in Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Montana and western Canada to support the production, storage and deployment of SAF in the Pacific Northwest. The coalition is planned to meet in late summer 2025.

title: Conestoga Energy acquires SAFFiRE Renewables to advance production of SAF
description:
Conestoga Energy has announced the acquisition of SAFFiRE Renewables, a process technology company that enables production of ultra-low carbon intensity ethanol and intermediates.
The acquisition includes all intellectual property, certain related technologies, the proposed pilot production facility, as well as key leadership team members, enabling Conestoga to further capitalise on the growing demand for reliable renewable fuels, including but not limited to sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.
“Sustainable aviation fuel represents a multi-billion-dollar market opportunity, and this acquisition positions Conestoga at the leading edge of efforts to bridge the critical supply-demand gap facing the aviation industry while creating transformative opportunities for American agriculture," said Tom Willis, CEO of Conestoga Energy.
“The IP acquired in this transaction will provide us with tremendous optionality not only as it relates to SAF feedstock production, but across our operations.

text:
Cemvita has signed an engagement agreement with Invest RS, formalising its plan to build a facility in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, for the production of FermOil™.

This sustainable oil will be used as feedstock for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production. The plant will also produce FermNPK™, an innovative biofertiliser that supports regenerative agriculture.

Earlier this year, Cemvita announced a partnership with Be8, a biofuel pioneer, also located in Rio Grande do Sul to strengthen the SAF value chain, reinforcing Be8's long term goal to become sustainable biofuel solutions provider.

“Rio Grande do Sul takes another important step toward becoming a global reference in innovation and bioeconomy. This partnership with Cemvita reinforces our commitment to sustainability, the attraction of high-impact investments, and the creation of opportunities for the people of Rio Grande do Sul in strategic sectors such as renewable energy, agriculture, and industry,” stated acting governor Gabriel Souza.

The facility will be used to produce low-carbon oil derived from crude glycerol, which will serve as feedstock for the production of SAF.

The site will also produce a biofertiliser that supports regenerative agricultural practices. Earlier this year, Cemvita announced a partnership with Be8, a biofuel pioneer also based in Rio Grande do Sul, to strengthen the SAF value chain—reinforcing Be8’s long-term goal of becoming a provider of sustainable biofuel solutions.

title: RI Challenged To Scientifically Prove Biodiesel As Clean Energy
description:
JAKARTA – Indonesia is facing a big challenge to prove that palm oil-based biodiesel is not just a slogan of reducing carbon emissions, but it is truly a sustainable energy solution that can be objectively and scientifically measured.
The biodiesel 35 percent (B35) program alone is claimed to have reduced emissions up to 34 million tons of CO₂ equivalent per year.
Indonesia has abundant source of wastes and palm oil derivative products that can be used as raw material for production of SAF.
Amid the global pressures on environment and domestic need for clean energy, Indonesia is now entering a crucial point to prove that palm oil-based biodiesel can really become a clean energy product of the future, and not just a biofuel with full of controversy.
RI Challenged To Scientifically Prove Biodiesel As Clean Energy.
text:
JAKARTA – Indonesia is facing a big challenge to prove that palm oil-based biodiesel is not just a slogan of reducing carbon emissions, but it is truly a sustainable energy solution that can be objectively and scientifically measured.

Edi Wibowo, Director of Bioenergy at the ministry of energy and mineral resources (KESDM) said the credibility of Indonesian biodiesel depends on the capacity to show real and measurable impacts to the reduction of carbon emissions.

“Now, it’s not the time to talk about claims that biodiesel is ecofriendly. We have to prove it scientifically that our palm-based biodiesel is truly sustainable and can compete globally,” Edi told participants of the 10th international conference of Biomass and Bioenergy (ICBB) in Bogor, West Java, on Monday (04/08/2025).

Indonesia’s mandatory program of biodiesel has been claimed to have reduced carbon emissions. The biodiesel 35 percent (B35) program alone is claimed to have reduced emissions up to 34 million tons of CO₂ equivalent per year. “But amid the global pressures on environment and deforestation, such claim needs to be supported by field data, transparancy of supply chain, and recognition from international institutions,” he said.

The Head of Surfactant and Bioenergy Research Center (SBRC), Meika Syahbana RuslI emphasized the importance of synergy between scientists, industrial players, and regulators. “Without collaborations, the green energy transition cannot be achieved and it will be just rethoric,” said Meika.

During the conference, the issue of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) or bioavtur for airplanes was also discussed by speakers and participants.

Although the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) has given a positive sign of support for the production of SAF based on palm oil and the used cooking oil (UCO), the production of SAF is still facing big challenges in terms of technical aspects, investments, and market acceptability.

Indonesia has abundant source of wastes and palm oil derivative products that can be used as raw material for production of SAF. But such big potential can be just dormant without the support of research activities, funding and adaptive policies from the government.

The Head of Services Division at the Oil Palm Plantation Fund Management Board (BPDPKS), Arfie Thahar, said that his institution is now accelerating the integration of technological research, public policies, and global access.

“If we want our biodiesel and bio-avtur products accepted at the global market, we have to implement a thorough improvement from the level of farmers to the tanks of vehicles. We cannot just rely on the green narrative alone,” said Arfie.

Amid the global pressures on environment and domestic need for clean energy, Indonesia is now entering a crucial point to prove that palm oil-based biodiesel can really become a clean energy product of the future, and not just a biofuel with full of controversy. (*)

title: Pragmatic Assessment of Meeting the 2030 U.S. Sustainable Aviation Fuel Goal - SSRN
description:
Abstract Sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production is essential for decarbonizing the aviation sector in the short and mid-term as well as maintaining the global competitiveness of U.S. airlines, supporting job creation, and ensuring U.S. energy independence.
In 2024 U.S. SAF production was less than 2% of the stated goal, demonstrating that the remaining production growth is significant.
Our analysis indicates that the hydroprocessed esters and fatty acids pathway will dominate U.S. SAF production through 2030, with notable contributions from alcohol to jet and co-processing.
Existing U.S. policies favor on-road transportation fuels and are insufficient to drive necessary SAF production scale-up.
These measures are needed to ensure the profitability of SAF production and competitiveness with renewable diesel.
text:
Abstract

Sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production is essential for decarbonizing the aviation sector in the short and mid-term as well as maintaining the global competitiveness of U.S. airlines, supporting job creation, and ensuring U.S. energy independence. The near-term U.S. SAF target, set by the SAF Grand Challenge, is 11.4 billion liters (3 billion gallons) of domestic SAF production by 2030, with a minimum 50% reduction in lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions. In 2024 U.S. SAF production was less than 2% of the stated goal, demonstrating that the remaining production growth is significant. Barriers to scale-up include technological readiness, feedstock availability, and delays in facility development. This study uses a database of U.S. SAF production announcements to assess the feasibility of attaining the 2030 targets by analyzing production potential, construction paradigms, feedstock availability, and CO2 abatement cost. Our analysis indicates that the hydroprocessed esters and fatty acids pathway will dominate U.S. SAF production through 2030, with notable contributions from alcohol to jet and co-processing. However, probable U.S. production of SAF is predicted to fall short of the current goal by 3.6-billion liters although there are scenarios that meet the goal. Existing U.S. policies favor on-road transportation fuels and are insufficient to drive necessary SAF production scale-up. Additional measures, such as non-government scope 3 emission purchases, long-term incentives, a national low-carbon fuel standard, or volume mandates, are options to close the gap. These measures are needed to ensure the profitability of SAF production and competitiveness with renewable diesel.

title: Indian Oil's Panipat Refinery achieves India's 1st ISCC CORSIA certification for sustainable ...
description:
New Delhi: In a landmark development for India’s clean energy sector, Indian Oil Corporation Ltd. (Indian Oil) has become the first company in the country to secure the International Sustainability & Carbon Certification (ISCC) CORSIA for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) production at its Panipat Refinery.
The certification is a prerequisite for commercial SAF production and marks a major step forward in India’s capability to produce, certify, and distribute sustainable aviation fuel in line with global standards.
The ISCC CORSIA certification, developed under the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), ensures that SAF meets stringent sustainability and lifecycle carbon emission standards.
SAF from Panipat Refinery has undergone comprehensive assessment for lifecycle emissions and traceability, enabling Indian airlines to integrate certified SAF into their operations.
With this milestone, Indian Oil reinforces its position as a leader in the nation’s energy transition and a key contributor to a greener aviation future.
text:
New Delhi: In a landmark development for India’s clean energy sector, Indian Oil Corporation Ltd. (Indian Oil) has become the first company in the country to secure the International Sustainability & Carbon Certification (ISCC) CORSIA for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) production at its Panipat Refinery. The certification is a prerequisite for commercial SAF production and marks a major step forward in India’s capability to produce, certify, and distribute sustainable aviation fuel in line with global standards.

The certification was formally handed over by international certifying agency Cotecna to Indian Oil's Chairman AS Sahney at a ceremony in New Delhi. The event was attended by Ministry of Petroleum & Natural Gas (MoP&NG) Joint Secretary Rohit Mathur; Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) Joint Director General Maneesh Kumar and senior officials from MoP&NG, DGCA, the Ministry of Civil Aviation (MoCA), and the National Accreditation Board for Certification Bodies (NABCB).

Speaking on the occasion, officials commended the coordinated efforts of MoP\&NG, DGCA, NABCB, MoCA, and Cotecna in aligning India’s regulatory and production frameworks with international best practices for green aviation.

The ISCC CORSIA certification, developed under the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), ensures that SAF meets stringent sustainability and lifecycle carbon emission standards. SAF from Panipat Refinery has undergone comprehensive assessment for lifecycle emissions and traceability, enabling Indian airlines to integrate certified SAF into their operations.

This achievement sets a benchmark for domestic refiners and industry players, supporting India’s goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2070. With this milestone, Indian Oil reinforces its position as a leader in the nation’s energy transition and a key contributor to a greener aviation future.

title: Israeli settler attacks on West Bank rise amid new illegal settlement plans - Thred
authors: Jessica Byrne, Anyaa Shrii Kumar, Flo Bellinger, Jamie Watts
description:
Since the start of this year, Israeli settlers have committed a record number of attacks on people and homes in the West Bank.
Israeli extremists are carrying out one of the most violent campaigns against Palestinian villages in the West Bank since 2006, when the United Nations first began keeping record.
According to the UN, at least 964 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli forces and settlers in the West Bank since October 2023.
A background on illegal settlements Since 1967, Jewish communities have been slowly building settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem.
This project, if completed, will connect Jerusalem and the existing illegal Israeli settlement of Maale Adumim, which is located several kilometres to the east.
text:
Since the start of this year, Israeli settlers have committed a record number of attacks on people and homes in the West Bank. These land grabs, which often violence and arson, continue as Israel’s far-right minister says he will approve more than 3,000 new illegal settlements in the area.

Israeli extremists are carrying out one of the most violent campaigns against Palestinian villages in the West Bank since 2006, when the United Nations first began keeping record.

Records collated by the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs reveal that more than 750 attacks on Palestinians and their property occurred during the first half of this year, averaging out to about 130 assaults a month.

Though Israel’s military has said it takes measures to prevent such attacks, an investigation by the New York Times found that ‘Israeli authorities have for decades failed to impose meaningful restraints on criminal settlers’.

Surveying security footage from cameras in the West Bank, the Times reports that many Israeli settlers enter Palestinian villages in the day time to carry out land grabs and forced displacement. This often sparks violent confrontation which has, all too often, led to the death of several Palestinians.

According to the UN, at least 964 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli forces and settlers in the West Bank since October 2023. At least 2,907 home demolitions were also carried out by Israel during the same period.

A background on illegal settlements

Since 1967, Jewish communities have been slowly building settlements in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. These settlements are considered illegal under international law, however it has not stopped the number of Israelis setting up camp in these areas from reaching around 700,000.

Research by the humanitarian organisation Peace Now shows that settlers are increasing their operations in recent years. Since the beginning of 2023, Israeli settlers have built more than 130 illegal outposts in rural parts of the West Bank – more outposts than were built over the last two decades combined.

The Times reports that settlement leaders acknowledge that ‘their aim is to intimidate Palestinians into leaving strategic tracts of territory’. Individuals leading these settler campaigns have been quoted saying that ‘it’s not the nicest thing to evacuate a population,’ but suggest that in a war over land, ‘this is what is done’.

Though some Israeli settlers choose to handle disputes in the daytime, others attack under the cover of night – spraying graffiti on the exterior of homes and, in some cases committing arson, lighting cars on fire and throwing fireballs through open windows of Palestinian homes.

Such attacks have grown in consequence since October 2023. In videos that have been circulated online, one settler can be seen shooting a Palestinian in the presence of an Israeli soldier. It has been confirmed that the shooter was questioned for only 20 minutes and never arrested.

Israel also launched a substantial military operation called ‘Iron Wall’ in January of this year, which forcibly displaced 40,000 Palestinians in the West Bank.

No signs of slowing

On 14 August, Israel’s far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich delivered a speech outlining his plan to approve thousands of housing units in a controversial and long-delayed illegal settlement project in the occupied West Bank.

In the announcement, Smotrich said the move ‘buries the idea of a Palestinian state’ by building more than 3,000 homes in the E1 area settlement project. He praised the project as ‘Zionism at its best’.

This project, if completed, will connect Jerusalem and the existing illegal Israeli settlement of Maale Adumim, which is located several kilometres to the east.

‘This reality finally buries the idea of a Palestinian state, because there is nothing to recognise and no one to recognise.’ Smotrich said. ‘Anyone in the world who tries today to recognise a Palestinian state will receive an answer from us on the ground.’

The Palestinian Ministry of Foreign Affairs called the new settlement plan an extension of crimes of genocide, displacement and annexation, and an echo of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s statements regarding what he called ‘Greater Israel’.

The E1 plan has not yet received final approval, which is expected next week. It’s unclear whether any world power will step in to stop these plans for settlement expansion.

Key Trends in the Digital Stethoscope Market

Surge in Sustainable Aviation Fuel Use: Bioethanol is gaining traction as a key ingredient for sustainable aviation fuel, cutting emissions in air travel. United Airlines plans to expand ethanol-based SAF to meet net-zero goals, with 15% of U.S. fuel blends now including bioethanol.

Flex-Fuel Vehicles Boost Demand: Flexible fuel vehicles (FFVs) running on high-ethanol blends like E85 are driving bioethanol use. Brazil reports over 80% of new car sales are FFVs, supported by government incentives.

Cellulosic Ethanol Innovations: Advances in cellulosic ethanol from non-food waste like corn stover are making production greener. The U.S. Department of Energy notes a 50% cost drop in cellulosic ethanol production.

Bioethanol in Power Generation: Bioethanol is increasingly used in power generation, like combined heat and power systems. Shell’s partnership for bioethanol-powered fuel cells aims to enhance energy efficiency in decentralized systems.

Growth Factors in the Digital Stethoscope Market

Push for Greener Fuels: Bioethanol’s popularity is soaring as a cleaner alternative to fossil fuels, cutting emissions significantly. Over 110 billion liters are produced globally, with the U.S. leading at 60 billion liters. Policies like the U.S. Renewable Fuel Standard drive demand.

Government Support Boosts Production: Governments worldwide are backing bioethanol with blending mandates and subsidies. India’s Pradhan Mantri JI-VAN Yojana funds second-generation bioethanol projects, aiming for net-zero emissions by 2070, spurring local production and jobs.

Transportation Sector’s Big Appetite: Bioethanol dominates transportation, especially in blends like E10, used widely in flex-fuel vehicles. The sector consumes the most bioethanol, with E10 blends making up 65% of U.S. production, reducing carbon emissions.

Innovations in Cellulosic Ethanol: Advances in cellulosic ethanol from non-food biomass like agricultural waste are gaining traction. Over 25 new plants are operational globally, with LanzaTech’s $100 million project converting industrial waste to ethanol.

Sustainable Aviation Fuel Surge: Bioethanol is powering sustainable aviation fuel (SAF), cutting aviation emissions. United Airlines and British Airways are investing in ethanol-based SAF, with projects aiming to produce 510 million liters annually.

title: The Search for Sustainable Aviation Fuels Is on Chopping Block - FlaglerLive

title: Cathay Pacific to Host IATA's World Sustainability Symposium - Travel Radar
description:
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) will be holding their third World Sustainability Symposium (WSS) on 21-22 October 2025.
IATA’s World Sustainability Symposium 2025 This year’s World Sustainability Symposium (WSS) will be held in Hong Kong and hosted by Cathay Pacific.
Cathay Pacific is the flag carrier of Hong Kong and has their head office and main hub both located at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA).
The airline continues to reinvest back into Hong Kong and sustainability efforts, including recent developments in recycling inflight food waste and the upcoming 2025 World Sustainability Symposium.
Notably, Cathay Pacific was recently named the third best airline in the world by Skytrax.
text:
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) will be holding their third World Sustainability Symposium (WSS) on 21-22 October 2025. The event will be hosted by Cathay Pacific and will bring together leading organisations across the aviation, energy, finance, and policy sectors in Hong Kong to progress aviation sustainability.

IATA’s World Sustainability Symposium 2025

This year’s World Sustainability Symposium (WSS) will be held in Hong Kong and hosted by Cathay Pacific. The Symposium is IATA’s flagship event on aviation sustainability, set to welcome over 500 organisations from around the world to advance the industry’s aim of achieving net zero CO₂ emissions by 2050. Airlines, fuel producers, investors, policymakers, and innovators will all be in attendance at the WSS, encouraging greater discussion and collaboration between sectors.

Taking place on 21-22 October, the Symposium will follow the 42nd ICAO Assembly, which will call for stronger government policy to support the industry’s transition to Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF). The WSS also precedes COP30 – the United Nations Climate Change Conference that seeks to boost climate action. Bridging these two significant events, the WSS will focus on removing obstacles to SAF production expansion, attracting financing for decarbonisation costs, integrating emerging technology developments, and increasing collaboration.

Willie Walsh – Director General of IATA – has highlighted the importance of the WSS and what it can do for the future of sustainable aviation:

“We are at a crucial point. Airlines are fully committed to achieving net zero carbon emissions by 2050. But we have not seen sufficient, timely action by policymakers, aerospace manufacturers, oil companies, or fuel producers to support this commitment. This event is an essential rallying call for all those who have a stake in air transport’s future to overcome any challenges in the way of accelerating the pace of this crucial energy transition.”

The symposium will feature speeches and conversations from:

Ronald Lam, Chief Executive Officer of the Cathay Group

Mable Chan, Secretary of Transport & Logistics for the Hong Kong SAR Government

Patrick Healy, Chair of the Cathay Group

Willie Walsh, Director General of IATA

Dr Jun Ma, Chairman & President of Hong Kong Green Finance Association

Dr Fabiano Piccino, Air Logistics Global Head of Sustainability at Kuehne+Nagel

Jouk Boeye, Managing Director Corporate Sourcing, Supply Chain Sustainability & Net Zero Operations at HSBC

Christopher AU, Director of the Asia Pacific Climate Risk Centre of WTW

Ayesha Choudhury, Chief Commercial Officer at Infinium

Lam has also commented:

“As the IATA World Sustainability Symposium lands in Asia for the first time, we are honored that Hong Kong has been selected as the location and Cathay Pacific as the host airline. Collaboration across multiple sectors and regulators is essential for aviation to achieve its decarbonization goals, and gatherings like this provide a valuable platform for leading voices to come together to drive meaningful change. Such cooperation is especially important as the industry works to develop the ecosystem of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), with Hong Kong having the potential to become one of Asia’s major centers for SAF in the future.”

About Cathay Pacific

Founded in 1946, Cathay Pacific has grown to operate a passenger fleet of 179 aircraft and a cargo fleet of 20 Boeing 747 freighters.

Cathay Pacific is the flag carrier of Hong Kong and has their head office and main hub both located at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA). The airline continues to reinvest back into Hong Kong and sustainability efforts, including recent developments in recycling inflight food waste and the upcoming 2025 World Sustainability Symposium.

As one of the founding members of the oneworld Alliance, Cathay Pacific is committed to global connectivity, providing services to over 190 destinations across 60 different countries. Notably, Cathay Pacific was recently named the third best airline in the world by Skytrax.

title: Pillen highlights vision to grow state's bioeconomy, creating opportunities for young people
description:
Workforce, manufacturing, and the bioeconomy are the three pillars of Gov.
Jim Pillen’s vision to grow the state and create opportunities for young Nebraskans.
Pillen hosted his annual Governor’s Summit in Kearney on Thursday, bringing together ag and business leaders with youth.
Husker Coach Matt Rhule kicked off the event, with an overflow crowd listening to the football coach just days before the start of the season.
Pillen also spoke with Deputy USDA Secretary Stephen Vaden, who spoke about the reconciliation bill, trade and tariffs, and other Trump administration priorities.
text:
Workforce, manufacturing, and the bioeconomy are the three pillars of Gov. Jim Pillen’s vision to grow the state and create opportunities for young Nebraskans.

Pillen hosted his annual Governor’s Summit in Kearney on Thursday, bringing together ag and business leaders with youth.

Husker Coach Matt Rhule kicked off the event, with an overflow crowd listening to the football coach just days before the start of the season.

Pillen noted that Rhule said success need to be “spoken into existence”. Pillen said the state “is giving topsoil away” by putting commodities on barges and said instead grain needs to be turned into sustainable aviation fuel and the building blocks of the new bioeconomy, where a kernel of corn can produce what the petroleum industry produces now.

Pillen also spoke with Deputy USDA Secretary Stephen Vaden, who spoke about the reconciliation bill, trade and tariffs, and other Trump administration priorities.

title: Aemetis reports progress with biofuel, biogas projects in Q2 earnings release
description:
August 14, 2025 BY Erin Krueger Aemetis Inc. released second quarter results, reporting increase revenue when compared to the first quarter of the year.
During an earnings call, company officials detailed progress with the company’s dairy renewable natural gas (RNG), ethanol, biodiesel, sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) projects.
Aemetis Executive Chairman and CEO Eric McAfee said progress is being made on the mechanical vapor recompression (MVR) project underway at the Keyes plant.
McAfee said the RNG business is steadily scaling up, with a new multi-dairy digester coming online this month that is expected to boost RNG production by 30%.
Aemetis reported second quarter revenues of $52.2 million, down from $66.6 million reported for the same period of last year.
text:
August 14, 2025

BY Erin Krueger

Aemetis Inc. released second quarter results, reporting increase revenue when compared to the first quarter of the year. During an earnings call, company officials detailed progress with the company’s dairy renewable natural gas (RNG), ethanol, biodiesel, sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and carbon capture and sequestration (CCS) projects.

Todd Waltz, chief financial officer at Aemetis, said the company’s ethanol plant in Keyes, California, operated at a slightly reduced rate of 13.8 million gallons during the quarter to maximize margins.

Aemetis Executive Chairman and CEO Eric McAfee said progress is being made on the mechanical vapor recompression (MVR) project underway at the Keyes plant. Key vendors are fabricating equipment for the system, he said, noting the MVR project is expected to reduce the plant’s natural gas use by 80%. The system is expected to be fully operational next year.

Advertisement

Advertisement

McAfee also noted that ethanol pricing has improved since earlier this year. He cited the U.S. EPA’s emergency waivers for E15 and lower corn prices as factors that have improved margins. While Aemetis decreased ethanol production during the spring to optimize margins, McAfee said the company has recently increased production to support market demand and participate in the higher-margin environment.

According to Waltz, Aemetis’s dairy RNG operations recognized $3.1 million of revenue from 11 operating digesters during the second quarter, suing the California Air Resources Board-approved Low Carbon Fuel Standard pathway for seven of the digesters.

McAfee said the RNG business is steadily scaling up, with a new multi-dairy digester coming online this month that is expected to boost RNG production by 30%. He said the company plans to reach 550,000 MMBtus of RNG production capacity this year, increasing to 1 million MMBtu by the end of next year.

Regarding Aemetis’ Riverbank project, a proposed 90 MMgy SAF and renewable diesel facility, McAfee confirmed the company has received the authority to construct air permits and conditional use permit for the project. He said the company is in active discussions on financing structure and is waiting further clarity on the 45Z production tax credit and Renewable Fuels Standard mandates to support project financing.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Aemetis is also planning to develop a CCS project at the site of the Riverbank facility. McAfee said initial site work is complete on a geologic characterization well. Data obtained from the next phase will support the company’s Class VI permit application with the U.S. EPA. Once permitting, the site is expected to have the capacity to sequester up to 1.4 million metric tons of CO2 annually.

Aemetis also has an India-based biodiesel business. That subsidiary is targeting a public listing in early 2026.

Aemetis reported second quarter revenues of $52.2 million, down from $66.6 million reported for the same period of last year. The dairy RNG segment produced 106,400 MMBtu and reported $3.1 million in revenue. The India biodiesel business recognized $11.9 million in revenue.

Gross loss for the second quarter was $3.4 million, compared to a $1.8 million gross loss reported for the same period of 2024. Operating loss was $10.7 million, compared to an operating loss of $13.6 million. Net loss was $23.4 million, compared to a net loss of $29.2 million.
